title: Conbini Are Life Savers
summary: Convenience stores (7-Eleven, Lawson, FamilyMart) do everything: ATMs for foreign cards, bill payment, ticket printing, package shipping, free hot water for noodles, clean toilets.

title: Lunch Sets Are Half Price
summary: The same restaurant that charges ¬•3000 for dinner often has ¬•800-1200 lunch sets (teishoku). Check the lunch menu board outside - it's a local secret for eating well cheaply.

title: Depachika Food Paradise
summary: Department store basement floors (depachika) have incredible food halls. Free samples are common. Before closing time (7-8 PM), items get discounted 20-50%.

title: Ticket Machines at Ramen Shops
summary: Many ramen shops have ticket machines (Âà∏Â£≤Ê©ü) at the entrance. Buy your ticket first, then hand it to staff. Don't worry - photos usually show what you're ordering.

title: Water is Always Free
summary: Restaurants provide free water („ÅäÂÜ∑„ÇÑ - ohiya) or tea automatically. You never need to order or pay for water. Just ask 'omizu kudasai' if not provided.

title: Last Order Warning
summary: Restaurants announce 'last order' („É©„Çπ„Éà„Ç™„Éº„ÉÄ„Éº) 30-60 min before closing. This is your final chance to order food/drinks. Staying past closing is considered rude.

title: Plastic Food Shows Actual Size
summary: The plastic food displays (È£üÂìÅ„Çµ„É≥„Éó„É´) outside restaurants show exact portion sizes. What you see is what you get - use them to decide before entering.

title: Nomihoudai Deals
summary: All-you-can-drink (È£≤„ÅøÊîæÈ°å nomihoudai) deals cost ¬•1000-2000 for 90-120 min. All-you-can-eat (È£ü„ÅπÊîæÈ°å tabehoudai) works similarly. Great value but time-limited.

title: Don't Pour Soy Sauce on Rice
summary: Pouring soy sauce directly on white rice is considered improper. Dip your food into soy sauce instead, or use the small dish provided.

title: Ginger is a Palate Cleanser
summary: At sushi restaurants, pickled ginger (gari) is meant to cleanse your palate between different fish - not to be piled on top of sushi.

title: Kampai Before Drinking
summary: Always wait for everyone to receive drinks, then say 'kampai!' (cheers) together before the first sip. Starting alone is considered rude.

title: Wait for Everyone to Eat
summary: Don't start eating until everyone at the table has their food. Say 'itadakimasu' together, then begin. The host or eldest often takes the first bite.

title: Chotto Means No
summary: 'Chotto...' („Å°„Çá„Å£„Å® - 'a little...') with trailing off actually means 'no' or 'that's difficult.' Japanese rarely say 'no' directly. Learn to read the hesitation.

title: The X Gesture
summary: Crossed arms or fingers making an X means 'no,' 'not available,' or 'closed.' Staff use this when they can't accommodate your request.

title: Teeth Sucking Sound
summary: When Japanese people suck air through their teeth (sss sound), it signals hesitation, difficulty, or that they're thinking of how to politely refuse.

title: 7-Eleven ATMs Best for Foreigners
summary: 7-Eleven and Japan Post ATMs are most reliable for foreign cards. Regular bank ATMs often reject overseas cards. Look for 'International ATM' signs.

title: Coin Locker Strategy
summary: Train stations have coin lockers („Ç≥„Ç§„É≥„É≠„ÉÉ„Ç´„Éº). Sizes range from ¬•300-700. Large sizes fill up fast - arrive early. Some accept IC cards. Note locker number!

title: Ekiben Station Bento
summary: Ekiben (ÈßÖÂºÅ) are special bento sold at train stations, often featuring local specialties. Eating ekiben on long-distance trains is a beloved tradition.

title: Night Buses Save Money
summary: Overnight highway buses between cities cost 1/3 of shinkansen fares. Not glamorous but practical. Book through Willer Express or Japan Bus Lines.

title: Last Train Times
summary: Last trains (ÁµÇÈõª shuden) run around 11:30 PM - 12:30 AM depending on the line. Miss it and you're stuck until 5 AM. Check times for YOUR station, not terminus.

title: Green Car is First Class
summary: Green cars („Ç∞„É™„Éº„É≥Ëªä) on trains are first class - you need a special ticket. Don't accidentally sit there with a regular ticket or you'll pay the difference.

title: Free Shinkansen Reservations
summary: With JR Pass, you can reserve shinkansen seats for free at JR ticket counters. Reserved cars are less crowded than non-reserved, especially during peak times.

title: Love Hotels Aren't Shady
summary: Love hotels offer clean, themed rooms with great facilities. 'Rest' (2-4 hours) or 'Stay' (overnight) rates. Often cheaper than business hotels. Anyone can use them.

title: Manga Kissa Emergency Stays
summary: Manga cafes (Êº´ÁîªÂñ´Ëå∂) offer cheap overnight stays with reclining chairs, showers, and unlimited drinks. Great if you miss the last train. Around ¬•1500-2500.

title: 100 Yen Shops Quality
summary: Daiso, Seria, and Can Do (100 yen shops) have surprisingly good quality items. Great for travel essentials, souvenirs, snacks, and random necessities.

title: Drug Stores for Cosmetics
summary: Drug stores (Matsumoto Kiyoshi, Sundrug, etc.) sell cosmetics and skincare much cheaper than department stores. Tax-free available. Staff can recommend products.

title: Recycle Shops Treasures
summary: Second-hand shops like Hard Off, Book Off, and 2nd Street sell quality used items cheap. Find vintage clothes, electronics, instruments, and collectibles.

title: Sales Seasons
summary: Major sales happen in January (New Year) and July (summer). Department stores and fashion brands slash prices 30-70%. Mark your calendar if shopping is your goal.

title: University Cafeterias Open to Public
summary: Many university cafeterias (Â≠¶È£ü gakushoku) welcome the public and serve meals for ¬•300-500. Great budget option near campuses. Look for signs saying ‰∏ÄËà¨Âà©Áî®ÂèØ.

title: Free Tissue Packets
summary: People handing out tissue packets on the street are advertising. Take them freely - it's normal and the tissues are useful (public restrooms may lack paper).

title: Heated Toilet Seats
summary: Japanese toilets have heated seats, bidets, and sound effects (to mask noise). Buttons are usually labeled in English. The big button is always flush.

title: Kairo Heat Packs
summary: In winter, buy kairo („Ç´„Ç§„É≠) disposable heat packs at convenience stores. They last 12+ hours. Stick-on versions go inside clothes. Locals swear by them.

title: Cooling Products in Summer
summary: Convenience stores sell cooling sprays, sheets, and neck coolers in summer. Locals use these constantly. Look for ÂÜ∑Âç¥ (cooling) products near the register.

title: Allergy Season is Brutal
summary: Cedar pollen (sugi) season in Feb-April is intense. Locals wear masks, take medicine, and suffer. If you have allergies, bring medication - local antihistamines are mild.

title: Garbage Day Confusion
summary: Residential areas have strict garbage collection schedules - different days for burnable, plastic, glass, etc. If staying in an Airbnb, ask your host about the rules.

title: Bicycle Parking Tickets
summary: Bicycles parked illegally get ticketed or impounded (¬•2000-3000 to retrieve). Use designated parking areas. Rental bikes often include parking spot info.

title: Clinics Closed Wednesdays
summary: Many clinics and small hospitals close on Wednesday afternoons and Sundays. For emergencies, large hospitals have 24/7 services. Save emergency numbers in your phone.

title: Pharmacy vs Drug Store
summary: Pharmacies (Ëñ¨Â±Ä) dispense prescriptions. Drug stores („Éâ„É©„ÉÉ„Ç∞„Çπ„Éà„Ç¢) sell OTC medicine. For specific medications, go to a pharmacy with a pharmacist (Ëñ¨Ââ§Â∏´Â∏∏Èßê).

title: The Ura (Back) Side
summary: Famous areas often have a quieter 'ura' (back) version. Ura-Harajuku, Ura-Namba, etc. have local shops without tourist crowds. Ask locals or search 'ura + [area name]'.

title: Morning Temple Markets
summary: Some temples hold morning markets (ÊúùÂ∏Ç) on specific days - Toji in Kyoto (21st), Kitano Tenmangu (25th). Arrive early for best selection of antiques, food, and crafts.

title: Bowing on Phone is Normal
summary: Japanese people bow while talking on the phone - even though the other person can't see. It's unconscious and shows how ingrained bowing is. You'll catch yourself doing it!

title: Don't Blow on Hot Food
summary: Blowing on hot food to cool it is considered poor manners. Wave your hand over it or wait patiently. For noodles, slurping helps cool them as you eat.

title: Standing Bars Are Cheap
summary: Tachinomi (Á´ã„Å°È£≤„Åø standing bars) are much cheaper than seated izakayas. Popular with salarymen after work. No table charge, quick service, local atmosphere.

title: Station Food Courts
summary: Train station buildings often have food courts („É¨„Çπ„Éà„É©„É≥Ë°ó) on upper floors with diverse options and reasonable prices. Less crowded than street-level restaurants.

title: Loppi and Famiport Machines
summary: Convenience store ticket machines (Loppi at Lawson, Famiport at FamilyMart) sell concert, event, and attraction tickets. Some things ONLY sell through these.

title: Luggage Forwarding Services
summary: Takkyubin (ÂÆÖÊÄ•‰æø) services send luggage to your next hotel for ¬•1500-2500. Drop off at convenience stores or hotels. Travel light between cities. Arrives next day.

title: Airport Luggage Delivery
summary: Send luggage directly to/from airports with Yamato or Sagawa. Drop off 2 days before flight. Pick up at airport counter. No dragging bags on trains!

title: Watch the Opening Bow
summary: Department stores open at exactly 10 AM with staff lined up bowing to entering customers. It's a small cultural moment worth witnessing. Mitsukoshi is famous for this.

title: Indoor AC is Freezing
summary: Japanese buildings are heavily air-conditioned in summer - bring a light jacket for trains, malls, and restaurants. The contrast with outdoor heat is shocking.

title: Kaitenzushi Budget Sushi
summary: Conveyor belt sushi (ÂõûËª¢ÂØøÂè∏) like Sushiro, Kura Sushi, and Hama Sushi serves quality sushi for ¬•100-200 per plate. Touch panels let you order specific items.

title: Gyudon Chains Are Lifesavers
summary: Yoshinoya, Matsuya, and Sukiya serve beef bowls 24/7 for ¬•400-600. Quick, filling, and everywhere. Order from the ticket machine or at the counter.

title: Food Courts Accept Singles
summary: Unlike some countries, eating alone in Japan is totally normal and common. Food courts, ramen shops, and chain restaurants are especially solo-friendly.

title: Oshibori Isn't for Face
summary: While some Japanese men wipe their face with the hot towel, it's technically improper etiquette. Hands only is the polite way, especially in nicer restaurants.

title: The Polite Refusal
summary: If you hear 'muzukashii desu ne' (that's difficult) or 'chotto...' with a pained expression, it's a no. Japanese avoid direct refusals. Accept gracefully.

title: Train Melody Departure Warning
summary: The jingle playing at stations means the train is about to leave. Don't run for it - another train comes soon. Running causes accidents and delays for everyone.

title: Apologies Don't Mean Guilt
summary: Japanese people apologize frequently even when not at fault - 'sumimasen' is used for thanks, excuse me, and sorry. It maintains social harmony.

title: Tatemae vs Honne
summary: Japanese culture distinguishes between public face (tatemae) and true feelings (honne). People may say yes but mean no. Pay attention to context and body language.

title: Gift Wrapping is Free
summary: Stores offer free gift wrapping (ÂåÖË£Ö housou) - just ask. Quality is impeccable. Useful for souvenirs. They may ask if it's a gift („Éó„É¨„Çº„É≥„Éà„Åß„Åô„Åã).
